chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected superficial vein thrombosis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Take a history. 
    • Ask about symptoms experienced, including the duration and severity. 
      • Superficial vein thrombosis is generally characterized by pain, tenderness, itching, and reddening of the skin, and/or hardening of the surrounding tissue. Pigmentation changes of the overlying skin are often observed. 
      • Symptoms typically develop over hours to days and resolve in days to weeks, although hardness of the vein may persist for longer (several weeks to months).
    • Identify risk factors for superficial vein thrombosis, such as varicose veins, prolonged immobilization, and a history of previous episodes.
  • Examine the person.
    • Superficial vein thrombosis most often occurs in the lower limbs (in the saphenous vein or its tributaries), and varicose veins are the most common risk factor.
      • Examine the legs for varicose veins and other signs of venous insufficiency. Examine the person standing and lying, and document the location and severity of any varicose veins. 
      • In people with pre-existing varicose veins, there is a tender 'worm-like' mass deep to the skin. The overlying skin is warm and erythematous, and there is often oedema of the surrounding area without generalized swelling of the whole limb.
      • In people without varicose veins, there is often a palpable cord, sometimes nodular, associated with warmth, tenderness, and erythema along the course of a non-varicose superficial vein.
    • Assess for signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE), which may occur in association with superficial vein thrombosis.
      • DVT is distinguished from superficial vein thrombosis by generalized pain and swelling of the leg that is not localized to a thrombosed vein.
      • Features of PE include dyspnoea, chest pain, and syncope.
      • Identify people with factors that put them at increased risk of developing DVT or PE, such as reduced mobility or a superficial thrombus that extends near where an affected superficial vein joins a deep vein (for example where the long saphenous vein joins the femoral vein at the groin).
    • Assess for other complications of superficial vein thrombosis, such as infection.
      • Suspect infected superficial vein thrombosis if there are features of cellulitis (acute onset of red, painful, hot, swollen, and tender skin) or an abscess, especially if the person has a fever.
  • Suspect migratory superficial thrombophlebitis if a person has repeated thromboses developing in superficial veins, at varying (or multiple) sites but most commonly in the leg.
  • Consider differential diagnoses in people with other atypical presentations of superficial vein thrombosis.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations and the clinical features of superficial vein thrombosis are based on a Cochrane Systematic Review on Treatment for superficial thrombophlebitis of the leg [Di Nisio, 2018], a Brazilian guideline Guidelines for superficial venous thrombosis [Almeida, 2019], a Canadian guideline Superficial thrombophlebitis, superficial vein thrombosis [Thrombosis Canada, 2018], and on expert opinion in review articles [BMJ, 2015; Cosmi, 2015; Scott, 2015; BMJ, 2018].

  • No diagnostic gold standards have been defined for superficial vein thrombosis. The symptoms and signs of are mostly attributable to its inflammatory components, such as pain, tenderness, swelling, warmth, and erythema, with a palpable cord along the course of a superficial vein. These clinical manifestations are straightforward, and objective testing may therefore not be considered to be mandatory for the diagnosis [Cosmi, 2015].
  • CKS recommends examining the legs for varicose veins because superficial vein thrombosis often occurs in the presence of varicose veins (present in up to 80% of people) with or without chronic venous insufficiency [Cosmi, 2015; BMJ, 2018; Thrombosis Canada, 2018]. 
  • The information on the different presentations of superficial vein thrombosis in people with varicose veins and people without is based on expert opinion in a review article [BMJ, 2018].
